author: Steve Pond
title: Writers Guild Awards: List of Winners (Updating Live)
text:
Writers Guild Awards: List of Winners (Updating Live) 
“This Is Us” wins for episodic drama Steve Pond | February 19, 2017 @ 4:40 PM 
The Writers Guild of America is handing out awards in simultaneous ceremonies in Los Angeles and New York. TheWrap will update the list of Writers Guild Awards winners as they are announced. 
The first award of the night went to the TV series “This Is Us,” which won the award for episodic drama for the episode “The Trip.” 
The WGA is the last of the major guilds to announce its awards, this year holding its ceremony only one week before the Oscars. Because the guild restricts its nominees to films written under the guild’s Minimum Basic Agreement, or produced by signatories to that agreement or the agreements of affiliated international guilds, it is not always reliable in predicting Oscar nominees or winners. 
Still, in the last 10 years, seven of the WGA’s original-screenplay winners and eight of its adapted-screenplay winners have gone on to take the Oscar. Also Read: How 'Hell or High Water,''Arrival' Screenwriters Use Genre to Talk About Today's America 
This year, though, the difference between the WGA and the Academy is skewed even further by the fact that the Academy’s Writers Branch ruled that “Moonlight” is an adapted screenplay. The WGA considered it an original one, because the work from which it was adapted, Tarell Alvin McCraney’s “In Moonlight Black Boys Look Blue,” was never produced or published. 
The ruling put three of the top screenplay contenders –“Moonlight,”“La La Land” and “Manchester by the Sea”– in the same brutally competitive Writers Guild Awards category, along with “Hell or High Water” and “Loving” (which the Academy also considered adapted, though they didn’t nominate it). 
Winners are indicated with *WINNER . 
ORIGINAL SCREENPLAY “Hell or High Water,” Written by Taylor Sheridan; CBS Films“La La Land,” Written by Damien Chazelle; Lionsgate“Loving,” Written by Jeff Nichols; Focus Features“Manchester by the Sea,” Written by Kenneth Lonergan; Amazon Studios/Roadside Attractions“Moonlight,” Written by Barry Jenkins, Story by Tarell McCraney; A24
